awd_titl_txt: P2C2: Characterizing East African Climate Through a Major Faunal Transition at 250 - 550 ka
awd_abstract_narration:
The great lakes region of tropical East Africa has been a magnet for human occupation and settlement since the origin of our species but currently is one of the most underdeveloped in the world. Meanwhile, the future climate trends of the region remain relatively unknown.  This project will provide a perspective from the past on the future hydroclimate of the Lake Malawi basin, against which climate models can be compared for more reliable predictions of rainfall and drought and thus offer a much needed technical basis for water management in the region. The results will also provide important context to the evolution of our species and other mammals of eastern Africa during a crucial time period of its archaeological and evolutionary history. The project will support graduate and undergraduate students with mentoring activities designed to improve the likelihood of success in future careers which address national environmental and societal needs.  The researchers will offer a workshop to secondary school educators that will bring hands-on experience with sediment cores.  The researchers and educators will work together on curriculum development about modern day environmental and climate concerns by creating tested teacher-prep materials.

Specifically, the research project will develop a high-resolution record of past temperature and rainfall in southern East Africa that spans a relatively well dated, recent, and significant evolutionary event that occurred sometime between 500 and 300 thousand years ago. The study will focus on the Lake Malawi basin in southern East Africa, where the Lake Malawi Drilling Project recovered the longest, high-resolution record of climate change yet to be recovered from the African continent. Researchers will analyze sediments in the Lake Malawi drill core at roughly a 1000-year interval for temperature and rainfall between 250 and 550 thousand years ago, as recorded by organic geochemical signals in the sediments (TEX86, leaf wax carbon and hydrogen isotopic composition). These analytical results will be compared to other such results from around the world, to seek commonality in the timing or direction of climate change. The team will also compare their results with climate model reconstructions of the region, to test the accuracy of various climate models that hindcast African climate, and to better comprehend what caused the observed climate behavior.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Lake Malawi, centered at 11oS latitude, is a large lake in East Africa (Figure 1).  It is as long as Lake Superior and almost twice as deep.  The Lake Malawi drilling project recovered 380 meters of sediment from the lake's deepest basin in 2005. It is a continuous record of climate change that extends back 1.3 million years.  We undertook organic geochemical analyses of the sediments to reconstruct temperature and rainfall over Lake Malawi for the period between 125 and 550 thousand years ago.  Lake sediments contain remnants of past organisms living within the lake as well as the plants surrounding the lake. Over time, as sediments accumulate on the lake bottom, a record of past life and environments is preserved. Here, we analyzed a group of compounds produced by aquatic bacteria, which change the number of methyl branches in their membrane lipids in response to growth temperature. We also examined the hydrogen isotopic composition of waxes from plants living next to the lake, and of lipids produced by cyanobacteria living within the lake, to establish the history of rainfall and lake water salinity, respectively. The primary objective was to determine if an extreme climate event occurred between 390 and 500 thousand years ago that could explain a well-known extinction event, in which 85% of large-bodied specialized grazers in the southern Kenyan rift gave way to similar taxa of smaller body size adapted to semi-arid, open grassland and shrubby terrain. 

Over the study period, Earth's climate repeatedly shifted between warm conditions (interglacials) like today and ice ages (glacials). Our results display, for the first time on the African continent, a strong cyclic signal of glacial-interglacial change, that can be readily aligned with ocean sediment records of the timing and intensity of past ice ages and warm interglacials (Figure 2A). We discovered that the Malawi basin was unusually cold during an ice age around 430,000 years ago, known as Marine Isotope Stage 12 (MIS 12), followed by an intense warming of ~9oC by 400,000 years ago (MIS 11).  This is about twice the magnitude of warming that occurred in Africa coming out of the last ice age 20,000 years ago.  The 9oC temperature rise was accompanied by an equally dramatic shift in rainfall (Figure 2B) - we were surprised to find that each of the ice ages in our record were relatively wet periods compared to the more arid interglacials, contrary to the history of rainfall in the Malawi basin from the last ice age, which was relatively arid, to the present relatively moist interglacial. A previous study demonstrated that Lake Malawi shifted from its present overflowing condition to as much as ~500m lower during arid times.  Our new records establish that lake level consistently shifts on glacial-interglacial cycles.

The intense warming from 430 to 400 thousand years ago, the most extreme warming that we observe between 125 and 550 thousand years ago, is referred to as Glacial Termination V, connecting the unusually cold ice age (MIS 12) to the warm interglacial, MIS 11.  We propose that the massive extinction of mammals in the southern Kenyan rift resulted either from the unprecedented cold temperature of MIS 12 or from the 9oC warming, accompanied by an equally dramatic shift in rainfall in the region.  While Lake Malawi is about 1000 km south of the Kenyan rift, the temperature shift was likely equally intense throughout much of Africa.  Conversely, the shift in rainfall, may well have been in the opposite direction of the Malawi basin, for there is a known anti-phased relationship between southern East Africa, where Lake Malawi is located, and more equatorial locations to the north.

This award supported several graduate and undergraduate students and provided them with meaningful research experiences and mentoring to increase the likelihood of their future success in careers that address national environmental and societal needs.

We taught a week-long teacher training workshop in August 2022 for middle school and high school STEM teachers. The teachers developed hands-on activities at the appropriate grade level using locally collected sediment and tree cores to teach students about climate change, which they have taken back to their classrooms. The middle and high school STEM teachers who participated in our workshop will continue to engage and excite a large number of students on issues relating to climate change in the coming years and thus the educational impact spans well beyond our teacher training workshop.

Our new quantitative temperature and semi-quantitative rainfall records for the Malawi basin will allow climate models to be tested for their hindcasting accuracy for this region of Africa where climate change has such a major impact on the welfare of subsistence agriculture and fisheries, on a continent that is projected to have 2.5 billion people, or one fourth of the world's population, by 2050.
